speaker: HELENA
text_entry: SCENE II. Athens. QUINCE'S house.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Is all our company here?

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: You were best to call them generally, man by man,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: according to the scrip.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Here is the scroll of every man's name, which is

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: thought fit, through all Athens, to play in our

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: interlude before the duke and the duchess, on his

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: wedding-day at night.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: First, good Peter Quince, say what the play treats

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: on, then read the names of the actors, and so grow

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: to a point.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Marry, our play is, The most lamentable comedy, and

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: most cruel death of Pyramus and Thisby.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: A very good piece of work, I assure you, and a

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: merry. Now, good Peter Quince, call forth your

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: actors by the scroll. Masters, spread yourselves.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Answer as I call you. Nick Bottom, the weaver.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Ready. Name what part I am for, and proceed.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: You, Nick Bottom, are set down for Pyramus.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: What is Pyramus? a lover, or a tyrant?

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: A lover, that kills himself most gallant for love.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: That will ask some tears in the true performing of

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: it: if I do it, let the audience look to their

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: eyes; I will move storms, I will condole in some

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: measure. To the rest: yet my chief humour is for a

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: tyrant: I could play Ercles rarely, or a part to

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: tear a cat in, to make all split.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: The raging rocks

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: And shivering shocks

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Shall break the locks

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Of prison gates;

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: And Phibbus' car

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Shall shine from far

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: And make and mar

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: The foolish Fates.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: This was lofty! Now name the rest of the players.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: This is Ercles' vein, a tyrant's vein; a lover is

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: more condoling.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Francis Flute, the bellows-mender.

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: Here, Peter Quince.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Flute, you must take Thisby on you.

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: What is Thisby? a wandering knight?

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: It is the lady that Pyramus must love.

speaker: FLUTE
text_entry: Nay, faith, let me not play a woman; I have a beard coming.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: That's all one: you shall play it in a mask, and

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: you may speak as small as you will.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: An I may hide my face, let me play Thisby too, I'll

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: speak in a monstrous little voice. 'Thisne,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Thisne;' 'Ah, Pyramus, lover dear! thy Thisby dear,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: and lady dear!'

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: No, no; you must play Pyramus: and, Flute, you Thisby.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Well, proceed.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Robin Starveling, the tailor.

speaker: STARVELING
text_entry: Here, Peter Quince.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Robin Starveling, you must play Thisby's mother.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Tom Snout, the tinker.

speaker: SNOUT
text_entry: Here, Peter Quince.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: You, Pyramus' father: myself, Thisby's father:

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Snug, the joiner; you, the lion's part: and, I

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: hope, here is a play fitted.

speaker: SNUG
text_entry: Have you the lion's part written? pray you, if it

speaker: SNUG
text_entry: be, give it me, for I am slow of study.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: You may do it extempore, for it is nothing but roaring.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Let me play the lion too: I will roar, that I will

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: do any man's heart good to hear me; I will roar,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: that I will make the duke say 'Let him roar again,

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: let him roar again.'

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: An you should do it too terribly, you would fright

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: the duchess and the ladies, that they would shriek;

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: and that were enough to hang us all.

speaker: ALL
text_entry: That would hang us, every mother's son.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: I grant you, friends, if that you should fright the

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: ladies out of their wits, they would have no more

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: discretion but to hang us: but I will aggravate my

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: voice so that I will roar you as gently as any

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: sucking dove; I will roar you an 'twere any

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: nightingale.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: You can play no part but Pyramus; for Pyramus is a

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: sweet-faced man; a proper man, as one shall see in a

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: summer's day; a most lovely gentleman-like man:

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: therefore you must needs play Pyramus.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Well, I will undertake it. What beard were I best

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: to play it in?

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Why, what you will.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: I will discharge it in either your straw-colour

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: beard, your orange-tawny beard, your purple-in-grain

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: beard, or your French-crown-colour beard, your

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: perfect yellow.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: Some of your French crowns have no hair at all, and

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: then you will play bare-faced. But, masters, here

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: are your parts: and I am to entreat you, request

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: you and desire you, to con them by to-morrow night;

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: and meet me in the palace wood, a mile without the

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: town, by moonlight; there will we rehearse, for if

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: we meet in the city, we shall be dogged with

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: company, and our devices known. In the meantime I

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: will draw a bill of properties, such as our play

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: wants. I pray you, fail me not.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: We will meet; and there we may rehearse most

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: obscenely and courageously. Take pains; be perfect: adieu.

speaker: QUINCE
text_entry: At the duke's oak we meet.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Enough; hold or cut bow-strings.

speaker: BOTTOM
text_entry: Exeunt
